item.title: Hello Sunshine Preview – You, The Desert, and Your Giant Robot Best Friend
item.content:encoded:
Dustborn and Dreamfall Chapters developer Red Thread Games is expanding beyond its usual boundaries of narrative games with Hello Sunshine, a survival RPG that the studio's creative director acknowledges isn't their usual beat, but is excited to bring its own narrative-focused spin on this desert survival game.

Ahead of the studio showing off Hello Sunshine during the PC Gaming Show today, I got the chance to check out a hands-off presentation given by Red Thread Games' creative director, Ragnar Tørnquist, and game director Jonathan Nielssen, showing a bit of gameplay and talking about their vision for Hello Sunshine.

Hello Sunshine puts you in a dystopian desert world where, thanks to corporations like Sunshine Industries (of which you are the last remaining employee), the planet is starting to resemble Arrakis, which is to say that the part of the world you'll be exploring is entirely engulfed in sand, and the sun is a constant threat. Thankfully, it doesn't seem like there are giant sandworms about, but there are small (and sometimes quite large) robots that have you doing your best Aloy impression with a bow and arrow at your disposal and a slew of arrow types to craft to help you take down every kind of rogue metal beast, big or small.

That said, combat isn't the core challenge to the experience; the challenge is to survive. You'll need to constantly search for resources to keep yourself alive and manage your time in the sun so you're not collapsing from total dehydration. And you'll need to do all of this while constantly moving forward, because you have a big, giant, walking tether with you at all times. A skyscraper-sized robot that not only keeps you alive, but is your best friend in this downtrodden world.

And it's your giant robot friend that makes Hello Sunshine an interesting prospect as a survival game. Survival players are used to managing resources and ensuring that they are not exposed to the elements for too long. And if your year has been anything like mine, you've also sunk a good chunk of hours into Dune: Awakening, where keeping yourself safe from the elements is key to your survival more than your ability to fight off enemies.

But in Dune: Awakening, I can stop under a rock and rest a while, waiting for the sun to pass. Hello Sunshine's continuous day and night cycle does mean you'll get the space to rest, but during the day, you can't stop moving because the robot won't stop moving.

The robot is constantly moving forward, driving the momentum of the game, and because your survival is tied to staying in the robot's shadow, your looting and exploration time is always limited. I think it's an incredibly interesting way to frame a survival game, especially one with a narrative slant, because survival in life is all about moving forward, about not being stagnant and losing track of where you're going. Hello Sunshine forces you into a constant state of motion while asking you to manage all of the other regular survival elements, which I think is an extremely interesting premise for a survival game.

Your robot pal does sit down and charge every evening, which gives you respite not just from the sun but from the game's forward pacing. You also don't have to stay entirely glued to the robot the whole time, and certain procedural elements can allow you to stray from the robot's path for longer than you would in a clear day, like sandstorms that block out the sun, letting you wander a little further on your own. You'll also earn upgrades deeper into the game that mitigate your reliance on staying glued to the robot, but leaving its side is always a risk. Even at night, you'll freeze to death if you're not near the robot, as it releases all the heat it collected from the day.

Corporations like the one you were still working for when the world ended may have been the planet's downfall, but what's left behind by them is also your salvation. You'll craft upgrades and improve your character's survival chances at resting stations set up by Sunshine Industries while your robot buddy sits down and charges for the night. A 3D printer takes all of the scraps and resources you collect during the day and turns them into whatever you need to prepare for the day ahead.

These rest stations are also where your relationship with the robot begins to build. During the presentation, Red Thread Games describes your relationship with your iron giant friend as that of our general relationship to ants - we don't notice them unless they make us notice them. While the robot charges for the night, the Sunshine Industries rest stations are also where you can upgrade the robot's capabilities. Slowly but surely, the robot begins to pay attention to you, and your relationship with the robot evolves.

Tørnquist also likened your relationship with the robot to that of a child-parent relationship. Kids grow up in their parents' shadow, and it's up to them to walk out of it into the light, and how that relationship evolves is at the core of the narrative for Hello Sunshine.

As for how Red Thread Games approaches telling that kind of story, the team will let players experience it for themselves once the game is in their hands. They wouldn't go deeper into the story, but described Hello Sunshine as a game where its mechanics are the muscles of the game, but its strength is at its heart, which is the story. The studio also didn't delve into the co-op gameplay, but did say that Hello Sunshine's co-op "reframes the story" and that you won't actually get "the full story" without playing both solo and in co-op.

As with every hands-off preview, we'll have to wait and see if Red Thread Games is able to pull everything off. It's stepping outside its comfort zone, but you'll never accomplish anything staying in your comfort zone. Hopefully, whenever Red Thread Games is ready to release Hello Sunshine (which is still without a release date), its time straying from its own giant robot comfort zone will have proven fruitful.

item.title: Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War IV Shown in New Story Trailer
item.content:encoded:
Publisher Deep Silver and developer KING Art Games (the German studio behind Iron Harvest) have released a new story trailer for Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War IV, the upcoming new installment in the real-time strategy series, as part of today's PC Gaming Show: Most Wanted 2025.

Black Library author John French is co-writing the game's 70+ mission campaign, which will be available in both solo and co-op play modes. Dawn of War IV is set on the war‑torn world of Kronus, where the Blood Ravens, the Necrons led by Chronomancer Thothmek, the Orks under Warboss Gorgutz and Guzcutta, and Technoarcheologist Potentia Delta‑9 all converge before the Dark Angels arrive to turn the tide for the Imperium.

The Dark Angels are a fully playable Space Marine faction across all modes, with their own commanders (Company Master Astoran and Chaplain Ezrael), missions interleaved with those of the Blood Ravens, and a distinct playstyle emphasizing large‑scale, all‑out warfare, whereas the Blood Ravens, the other Space Marine chapter playable in the game, are often engaged in smaller conflicts that require stealth and/or tactical finesse. According to the press release, Primarch Lion El’Jonson will also appear in the campaign's climax as a playable unit, giving players direct control of a Primarch for the first time in the series.

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War IV will include four playable factions (the Space Marines, Orks, Necrons, and the Adeptus Mechanicus), multiple non‑linear campaigns, competitive multiplayer (1v1, 2v2, and 3v3), and returning modes like Last Stand and Skirmish. The game is slated to launch next year on PC. KING Art Games still hasn't shared the official system requirements, but we'll let you know once they are confirmed by the development team.

item.title: Neath, the Rogue Legacy devs' RPG set in an "irradiated, inverted tower" warped by godly whims, arrives 2026
item.content:encoded:
Get ready to "ascend the corrupt citadel to defy the decree of the undivine" in Cellar Door Games' latest work

"PRAISE NEATH", cry the developers of Rogue Legacy. "What's Neath?", I ask politely. It's their new game, they say, a roguelike RPG with some tactical combat about an upside-down tower constantly shifting because a god can't make up his mind. It's out next year, they add, before their fingers lose grip on the ceiling and they crash down from their inverted positions.

"Lead a band of fragile warriors through a colossal, inverted tower, where Taboos, the everchanging edicts of a God, warp the laws of reality," reads the start of the game's cracking synopsis. The tower's pointy, but stout, with its orientation meaning that it's hanging rather precariously above a city in a crater. Think an infernal robo-stalactite. The city has a tavern, for the love of all that's roguelikey, won't someone think of the ale?

Anyway, my fear of things falling aside, you head into the tower with your party, where gridded battle rooms await. The order of turns is always shifting and the goal is to think one step ahead, anticipating enemies' moves. Each run aims to be like a classic dungeon-crawl, with the usual roguelike twists and turns to keep things fresh and have you uncover more clues to the dark mystery that needs solving.

Cellar Door co-founder and lead programmer Kenny Lee cites Subset Games' mech strategy-fest Into the Breach and board game Mansions of Madness as Neath's inspirations. "Development has taken us far from our comfort zone, working in an unfamiliar genre with an aesthetic much darker than what we usually do," he said. "But we’ve got a lot of new ideas, from 'engagement locking' to the 'attack resolve system', and we’re excited to see if we can move this burgeoning genre in a whole new direction."

Neath's currently being aimed for a 2026 release on Steam. Cellar Door are planning some closed betas next year, which you'll be able to throw your name in the hat for via the studio's Discord. Here are former RPSer Ed Thorn's thoughts on Rogue Legacy 2 if you're in need of something to tide you over 'til then.

item.title: Sable creative director's new studio Eteo are aiming to release their first game in 2027, and have a newsletter starting next year
item.content:encoded:
Archetypes, the newsletter, will focus on examining "unsung aspects of video game design"

Gregorios Kythreotis, the creative director of sci-fi hoverbike adventure Sable, has a new thing. He's heading up a fresh studio dubbed Eteo, who'll be aiming to release their first game in 2027. Until then, the studio plan to start putting out a newsletter called Archetypes, which'll debut in January and discuss different elements of game design.

Eteo will be focused on "making vibrant game worlds with a distinctly mischievous flavour", and have funding in place from Outersloth, the indie game fund run by Among Us developers Innersloth, for that unnamed first game.

"We started [Sable studio] Shedworks about a week after I graduated from studying architecture," Kythreotis recalls in the studio announcement video above. "We've just basically been teaching ourselves on the job for a decade now. Sable was our first really big game, it changed my life completely. Eteo is sort of the next step with that. Taking everything I've learned from studying architecture, from shedworks, from Sable, and applying that to new creative explorations, projects that are really personal, but carry on with that lineage of world building, of storytelling, and games that really engage people on an emotional level."

Starting in January 2026, the studio will be putting out Archetypes, a free monthly newsletter. For the next half a year making up a first volume, it'll see three writers per month "examine unsung aspects of video game design with each article examining themes relevant to Eteo’s design philosophies". The first month's theme is "Flying Cities", with Citizen Sleeper creator Gareth Damian Martin having been drafted in to contribute, alongside Eteo Community Manager Emma Kent and two-time RPS contributor Christian Donlan.

If you're interested in Archetypes, you can sign up to receive it via Eteo's website. Then maybe spend the wait until the first issue re-reading former RPSer Alice B's review of Sable. Come on, you know you want to.

item.title: Fortnite Frees The Nipple
item.content:encoded:
One thing I love about this job is learning something new about games I do not play. That includes learning that Fortnite has historically either obscured or omitted male nipples in its various skins. Until now, that is. Homer Simpson was the first man to free the nipple last month, and now new character Carter Wu is getting a skin that lets him bare it all.

As IGN lays out, Fortnite has featured several shirtless skins of both fictional characters and real-world figures, but each of them has either covered up their chest, like putting a pelt on Kratos from God of War, or just not rendering their nipples, like rapper Travis Scott or wrestler/actor John Cena. 

This is odd, but not unheard of. Some anime or anime-inspired series like Free! or Persona do the same thing. However, after Homer and now Carter Wu have been added to Fortnite with nipples intact, it seems like Epic Games might have changed whatever internal rules it had about depicting male anatomy in the game.

Fortnite has thousands of skins, so I don’t think there’s a chance in Hell that Epic goes back and rectifies this for every shirtless man it’s ever rendered, but maybe this means that future skins won’t hide or remove male nipples moving forward.

In other Fortnite news, the crossover battle royale is the latest game to be caught in the generative AI witch hunt. This hasn’t been helped by Epic Games’ CEO Tim Sweeney ranting and raving about how developers shouldn’t have to disclose the use of AI to create in-game assets.

item.title: Liquid Swords’ First Game, ‘Samson: A Tyndalston Story’ Looks Like a GTA Competitor
item.content:encoded:
Liquid Swords, the new studio founded by Just Cause creator Christofer Sundberg, has officially unveiled its debut game at the PC Gaming Show today. The earliest teasers for this game pointed to a gritty, narrative-driven open-world title that many likened to Grand Theft Auto 4 in its aesthetic, but now we know exactly what we’re getting into.

In the run-up to the PC Gaming Show, Sundberg and Liquid Swords were all over social media, posting screenshots and talking extensively about ‘Game 1’ coming out of the new studio.

Liquid Swords Asks Gamers to Brace for Impact

Founded by Christofer Sundberg, the co-founder of Avalanche Studios and the creative force behind Just Cause, Liquid Swords has just revealed its inaugural title, Samson: A Tyndalston Story.

This project has been in the works since 2020, and the early teasers posted online referenced a bleak cityscape, suggesting similarities to games like Grand Theft Auto and Max Payne. All we knew previously was that the game was being built in Unreal Engine 5 and that it would be a far cry from Sundberg’s previous titles, like the over-the-top, explosive action series, Just Cause.

The PC Gaming Show played host to the game’s first major trailer, which you can see below:

In the lead-up to the trailer dropping, Sundberg revealed that the team at Liquid Swords features talent from Avalanche, Rockstar Games, and other major studios, which makes for a promising road ahead, given the team’s pedigree.

The trailer uncovered a gritty crime thriller backed by gruff voices, muscle cars, and gorgeous visuals. It looks like a perfect contender for games like Grand Theft Auto, which is a very ambitious thing to suggest.

Do you think Samson: A Tyndalston Story looks like your kind of game? Let us know what you’re thinking about Liquid Swords’ first title on the Insider Gaming Discord server.

An unlikely pair, an unforgettable journey.

item.title: Fullbright announces narrative exploration game Springs, Eternal for PC
item.content:encoded:
Fullbright has announced Springs, Eternal, a lo-fi first-person narrative exploration game set in a mysterious hot springs in the dead of night. It is a two-to-three-hours experience, and will launch for PC via Steam in 2026.

Here is an overview of the game, via Fullbright:

About

Springs, Eternal is a lo-fi first-person story exploration game that takes place at a mysterious hot springs in the dead of night, its evocative visual style recalling the dithered and pixelated graphics of late ’90s-era PC and home console games. Immerse yourself in this eerie, half-remembered otherworld, its dark, winding paths at once inviting and unsettling. Meet the other lost souls who have been drawn to this place. Relive your memories of the romantic relationship that brought you here.

Lose yourself. Seek something else.

Key Features

  • A short, focused, supernatural-inflected first-person narrative exploration game (around two-to-three hours to fully complete.) The dark paths you walk are ominous, but you can’t die… can you?
  • Experience all that a mysterious, secluded hot springs retreat has to offer. Multiple tucked-away pools, caverns, and other odd attractions. The map gradually expands as you explore, revealing new discoveries.
  • Over a dozen unique characters to encounter. Talk with them face-to-face, exploring topics via branching dialogue. Learn their stories and how they relate to your own.
  • Delve into a series of memories reliving the romantic relationship that brought you to this point. Flashbacks create a portrait of two people, their life together, and who they’ll become.
  • Evocative lo-fi graphics express the essence of this place through shimmering pixels and dithered fog.
  • Criss-cross the paths of Stillwater Springs using what you learn in one conversation to unlock new dialogue threads and new guest interactions elsewhere. Use your powers of observation to unearth all that Springs, Eternal has in store.

A look at the game's combat and multiplayer features.

Seed Lab has released a new trailer for anime-inspired life simulation game Starsand Island, as well as new information about the game’s combat and multiplayer features.

Here are the details:

Revealed during today’s PC Gaming Show, in addition to the calm, tranquil farming and friendship building showcased to date, Starsand Island will feature third-person combat mechanics when players explore the island’s mystical, ruined area. As players encounter the many strange animals that live among the ruins, they’ll use a range of weapons, including slingshots and bows, to remove a magical corruption from the creatures, enabling them to be domesticated.

Powerful animal bosses also live among the ruins, presenting a further layer of challenge. Overcoming them will take skill to exploit the creatures’ weaknesses, upgrade weapons and ammo, and perfectly time counters, but with the promise of greater rewards – including unlocking advanced professions to master—it’s a risk worth taking!

  • ❮
  • ❯

Exploring the ruins and battling its strange inhabitants doesn’t have to be a solo experience; like the rest of Starsand Island life, it can also be enjoyed online with a friend, as part of the game’s multiplayer. Players will also be able to invite friends to help build their idyllic, pastoral life, as they plant and harvest crops, fish and master animal husbandry, and construct a perfect home. They can also share vehicles or ride the larger animals, and adventure across the length and breadth of the island.

Today’s reveal also highlighted a number of advanced features available to players on their journey to exploring the simple life: The addition of smart robots will help automate farming, ensuring the harvest is reaped while players are away from their homestead—perhaps on a futuristic hoverboard—while custom glasshouses built in DIY mode will harness the sun’s energy to further help with plant propagation.

Starsand Island is due out for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, Switch 2, and PC via Steam, and Microsoft Store in early 2026.

item.title: Science-fiction puzzle adventure Rivage announced for PC
item.content:encoded:
Publisher Raw Fury and developer Exnilo Studio have announced science-fiction puzzle adventure game Rivage for PC (Steam). It will launch in 2026.

Here is an overview of the game, via its Steam page:

About

In the 25th century, humanity has been forced to expand beyond its solar system. Among the stars, the planet VESTA is discovered, a world that may hold the promise of a new home. To study it, the A.R.E.S. space station is launched into orbit to analyze its potential. But when the station, and the crew, was caught up in a space phenomenon, calamity struck…

You play as Miranda, who awakens alone aboard the station trapped in a strange phenomenon. With clues of the past echoing through the world: an object out of place, a door newly unlocked, a message left behind almost as if the station itself challenges you. To survive, Miranda must rely on her mind, solving intricate puzzles, experimenting with strange objects, and piecing together the truth behind what happened to her crew and the station itself.

As Miranda unravels the mystery, one truth becomes clear: progress always has a cost. Rivage is an atmospheric science-fiction puzzle adventure that blends exploration, logic, and narrative discovery into a deeply beautiful experience, where each step brings you closer to escape.

Key Features

  • Immersive World – Step aboard the A.R.E.S. station, a meticulously detailed, fully interactable environment where every item tells a story. Examine artifacts, analyze research data, and uncover hidden notes scattered across abandoned workstations.
  • Captivating Storytelling – The station was once home to a crew, each with their own goals, fears, and philosophies. Now, only fragments of their lives remain: journals, personal logs, and encrypted messages scattered throughout the station. Piece together their relationships, uncover the emotional toll of isolation, and experience a narrative that weaves scientific mystery with human vulnerability.
  • Unravel the Mystery – Every puzzle in Rivage is woven into the fabric of the story. You’ll repair broken systems, realign malfunctioning mechanisms, and solve environmental challenges that play with gravity, magnetism, and the very flow of time.
  • The K9 System – With the K9 System, Miranda can log discoveries and retain certain puzzle solutions, allowing players to focus on what truly matters; uncovering the truth behind the distortions that have consumed the station. This balance keeps gameplay engaging, rewarding cleverness and persistence over repetition.

item.title: Just Cause Creator Revs Up With New Action Game Samson
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

In 2020, Just Cause creator and Avalanche Studios founder Christofer Sundberg started a new company, Liquid Swords, alongside other industry veterans. Now, the team at Liquid Swords has shared the first trailer for its debut action title, Samson: A Tyndalston Story. It may remind some fans of Grand Theft Auto, but there are differences that make it a lot harder to earn money in this game.

Tyndalston is the name of the city, and players will step into the role of Samson McCray, an aging criminal who is facing a crushing debt. Players can steal the money they need, but this isn't like other open-world crime games where you can keep going non-stop. Samson has physical limits as to what he can pull off in a day, which are measured by action points. Use too many on a single job and you won't be able to do much else.

As time passes in this world, your debt increases. For every crime you commit, the city remembers and your reputation grows. According to Liquid Swords, "There are no do-overs. You move forward because standing still makes everything worse." This is a story about debt, consequences, and survival. Samson will have to deal with all three on a daily basis.

"We built Samson to strike fast and leave a mark," said Sundberg in a statement. "It's a raw, physical story with systems that push back at every turn. This is the start of what Liquid Swords stands for, and the team has delivered something with real teeth. We've come through a heavy cycle of change and sharpened every part of how we work. The entire industry is navigating pressure right now. Samson is our answer to that reality, a focused project built with intent, not excess. This is how we move forward."

Samson: A Tyndalston Story will be released on PC in early 2026 on Steam and the Epic Games Store.

item.title: Best Warzone And BO7 Perks For Season 1
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 has integrated with Warzone for Season 1, adding the full BO7 weapon pool, attachments, and other gear into battle royale. The big update also overhauls Warzone's perk system, so here we'll highlight all the perks in the game and include some recommended picks for your next match of battle royale.

Season 1 removes the Wildcard perks from Black Ops 6, and instead, you'll have Overkill by default. This means you can equip a second primary weapon without the need to select any specific perks to your loadouts.

The update also changes how some of the perks work in Warzone. Popular choices from last year may not be as beneficial this year, while other perks are buffed to be much more viable for Black Ops 7's integration.

The recommended perks can be great choices whether playing on Warzone's Verdansk or the new Haven's Hollow Resurgence map.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • All perk 1 (blue) options
    • Mountaineer
    • Cold-Blooded
    • Grenadier
    • Scavenger
    • Veteran
  • Best perk 1 options
  • All perk 2 (red) options
    • Bomb Squad
    • Reactive Armor
    • Sprinter
    • Alertness
    • Quick-Fix
  • Best perk 2 options
  • All perk 3 (yellow) options
    • Adaptive
    • Ghost
    • Survivor
    • Tracker
    • Tempered
  • Best perk 3 options

All perk 1 (blue) options

Mountaineer

This perk reduces fall damage and improves climbing with the following:

  • Increases the height before taking critical fall damage by five meters
  • Combat Roll mechanic further reduces fall damage by 10% and removes the movement penalty from high falls
  • Increases ladder climb speed by 15%

Cold-Blooded

Grants immunity to tracking equipment, targeting systems, and electronic interference with the following:

  • Immune to thermal optics, weapon targeting systems, heartbeat sensors, phantom signals, scrambling, EMP effects, Tracker, and Alertness

Grenadier

Improves explosive equipment and equipment handling with the following:

  • Explosive equipment adds a 5-second health regen delay
  • Explosive equipment inflicts a 20% movement slow for three seconds
  • Throw equipment 15% farther
  • See equipment trajectories

Scavenger

Improves ammo and resource acquisition with the following:

  • Dead opponents drop a pack containing additional ammo, equipment, plates, and cash

Veteran

Improves equipment resistance and long-range weapon handling with the following:

  • Resistant to flash, concussion, gas, and shock equipment effects
  • Immune to Grenadier
  • Increases hold-breath duration by five seconds
  • Increases flinch resistance by 30%

Best perk 1 options

Scavenger

Scavenger remains a solid choice for a first perk, as you can easily get topped off with ammo, armor plates, and cash by scavenging enemy players. I also think it's always good to have at least one class with this perk in case you need a quick regain after dying.

Mountaineer

Mountaineer has been readjusted to make it much more useful. This could be a great perk for aggressive players, who are looking to push fights and drop down on their opponents from above.

All perk 2 (red) options

Bomb Squad

Provides explosive resistance and equipment negation with the following:

  • Reduces explosive and fire damage by 45%
  • Spot and hack equipment through walls
  • Highlight equipment for your squad while ADS

Reactive Armor

Improves armor recovery and defense with the following:

  • Armor regenerates up to 100% of its maximum if you avoid damage for two seconds
  • Total approximated time to regenerate to maximum is 20 seconds
  • Breaking armor triggers an EMP effect (won’t re-trigger until armor is fully restored)

Sprinter

Improves sprinting and movement with the following:

  • Grants Tactical Sprint
  • Reload while Tactical Sprinting
  • Reduces movement penalties while reloading or using equipment

Alertness

Improves situational awareness with the following:

  • Sense opponents within 30 meters
  • Sense when you are being aimed at

Quick-Fix

Improves armor handling and health regeneration with the following:

  • Insert plates one-handed
  • Immediately begin health regeneration when eliminating opponents or inserting armor plates

Best perk 2 options

Bomb Squad

This was a popular pick in recent seasons of Warzone, and now the perk has been buffed to also include some fire-based resistance. Bomb Squad is great for aggressive plays, making sure you can see enemy equipment before pushing into buildings, as well as reducing the fire and explosive damage you take.

Alertness

It's always great to have intel on the map, especially when teaming up in trios or squads. Having at least one person in your party run Alertness will help warn you when an enemy has their sights on you.

All perk 3 (yellow) options

Adaptive

Improves explosive defense, movement, and handling with the following:

  • With plates not full: Gain a 10% movement speed boost
  • With plates full: Gain improved ADS speed and sprint-to-fire speed
  • Gain an audible warning when near trap equipment
  • Traps triggered by the player are delayed
  • Gain the ability to reset fuses when throwing back grenades

Ghost

Improves stealth with the following:

  • Undetectable by enemy radar pings while moving
  • Effects are disabled if stationary for 1.5 seconds or more

Survivor

Improves health regeneration, revive speed, and survivability with the following:

  • With full armor plates, gain one-hit protection against ballistic weapons
  • Health begins regenerating after 4 seconds
  • Allies revive you faster

Tracker

Improves tracking and target acquisition with the following:

  • Shooting an enemy briefly outlines them based on range
  • Automatically ping the enemy who downs you
  • Track enemy footprints; when you shoot an enemy, all others can see their footprints for 10 seconds

Tempered

Improves armor efficiency with the following:

  • Refilling armor requires 2 plates instead of 3

Best perk 3 options

Unfortunately, there are a lot of powerful perks stacked in slot 3, so which perk you pick will likely depend on your playstyle. This includes defensive perks that will help keep you alive, and an offensive perk designed for intel and aggressive plays.

Survivor

This was already a helpful pick in recent seasons of Warzone, but it becomes even more powerful in this new year with BO7's integration. In addition to the health regen and faster revives, it also now protects you from getting one-hit by snipers so long as you're geared up with full plates.

Tracker

Tracker is the pick for aggressive players looking to hunt their opponents. This will let you track and ping enemies just as before, but now the perk gives the added benefit of also letting your teammates see the enemy footprints after you shoot an enemy. Put some bullets in your opponent, but they are trying to flee? Now, you and your team can work together to track their steps and hunt them down.

Ghost

It's always helpful to have a Ghost class in Warzone, but the perk is very situational. There are some matches where your opponents just aren't calling in a lot of UAVs, and it might be better to have Tracker or Survivor as your third perk. Make at least one Ghost class, and this is something you can switch to if you find there are a lot of UAVs getting activated, or to keep you off the radar in a late-game situation.

Adaptive

This is a brand-new perk that the developer says is designed to allow you to dynamically respond to combat situations. When your armor plates are full, it supports aggressive pushes. When plates are depleted, it grants a constant movement advantage to aid you in repositioning.

This perk could be really useful in various situations, but it will require some testing to see if the ADS and speed boosts are enough to make this a viable pick, but it's worth trying out to see if you find this beneficial to you.

item.title: New Dawn of War 4 story trailer reveals surprise inclusion of Dark Angels sub-faction and everyone's favourite 10,000+ year-old grandpa
item.content:encoded:
A new story trailer for Dawn of War 4 has just been revealed, showing off the Dark Angels as a playable sub-faction, and teasing the old and busted Lion El' Johnson who appears to actually be hanging around his kids for once.

The trailer also gives us some more context as to why the four playable factions are back on Kronus, with Blood Ravens and Orks clashing like the good ol' days, while the Adeptus Mechanicus explore Necron tombs. We see a variety of units new to the series, including a Chaplan on bike, Necron skorpekh destroyers and an Ork Beastboss.

Lion El' Johnson interestingly enough has his helmet on at the tail end of the trailer, which may have prevented some from noticing his presence in the trailer. However, given we see his shield on full display, that's certainly him!

We also now know that the Dawn of War 4 campaign has been written by Black Library author John French. He's written plenty of Warhammer books over the years. This includes books focused on Ahriman, the first captain of the Thousand Suns legion. There's been a long-running fan theory that the Blood Ravens are successors of the Thousand Sons, so who knows? Maybe John French will drop a breadcrumb or two.

Other interesting tidbits from the trailer include the fact warboss Gorgutz is still alive and kicking. This makes sense as the Orks canonically were the victors of Dawn of War: Soulstorm, thus Orks would still be milling about the place. The Necrons have been fleshed out a bit too, ironically.

During the campaign, players will be able to pick between Dark Angels and Blood Ravens missions, allowing a degree of choice depending on which Space Marine faction you vibe with the most. These missions are "non-linear" according to the official press release for this story trailer.

Dawn of War 4 is set to release sometime in 2026, though you can wishlist it now! If you want to get an idea of what it's like, why not read our Dawn of War 4 preview. In it, writer Chris Tapsell stated: "it feels like the sequel to the original that RTS fans always wanted".

item.title: Den of Wolves drops a new gameplay trailer, but they’re keeping the release date a closely guarded secret
item.content:encoded:
One of the highlights of my writing this year was heading out to meet the team from 10Chambers at the European Unity headquarters, and getting to go hands-on with Den of Wolves. This futuristic heist game has a hell of a legacy – 10Chambers’ studio founder Ulf Anderson was the creator of Payday and GTFO – and even in our short time with the game, it was clear that the mix of planning, gunplay and crazy Inception-like sections was looking to be something special. While they’re continuing to work hard on the forthcoming game, 10Chambers are continuing a drip-feed of information, this time showcasing a new trailer, where they let four of the key community members for the game go hands-on. It looks like they had a pretty good time.

Robin Björkell, the Communications Director at 10 Chamber said, “I’ve been begging management to give us a release window for Den of Wolves in the trailer – but no. They won’t budge. These developers really don’t want to make promises they can’t keep for the sake of marketing. It makes my job harder, but as a gamer myself, I respect it. I told them we at least need to prove that the game exists, and that was the starting point for this trailer. We invited some of our most loyal fans to come to our office and play the game. This is real footage of them playing the game – not scripted, not us playing. The game does exist – ask them,”

In fact, you can hear from one of them straight away, with RandomKenny, one of the invited players, saying, “Absolutely incredible experience being invited to play Den of Wolves early. Planning and executing how you’re going to tackle heists is super satisfying. I had such a blast playing, and I honestly can’t wait for the game to be released”.

In the trailer, the players can be seen tackling a heist in a previously unseen level inside a robot factory. Inside this gigantic factory, the players face resistance from both human and robotic enemies, all while deploying spider drills to hack vaults full of valuables.

Obviously, the big question remains, just when will Den of Wolves release? The team are remaining tight-lipped despite the huge groundswell of community interest, and it doesn’t look like we’re going to get a set date any time soon.

item.title: Haddonfield Heights Multiplayer Map Revealed For IllFonic's Halloween
item.content:encoded:
IllFonic released a new trailer for its asymmetrical multiplayer horror game, Halloween, during today's PC Gaming Show, and it showcases its first map, Haddonfield Heights. Of course, Haddonfield is the fictional Illinois town where killer Michael Myers attempts to kill Laurie Strode in the original 1978 Halloween film, so it's no surprise a map like this is in the game. 

Developer-publisher IllFonic and co-publisher Gun Interactive describe Haddonfield Heights as a map nestled beneath the iconic Haddonfield water tower that brings players deep into the heart of the town, "introducing a warm, tight-knit neighborhood that hides terror behind every picket fence and perfectly manicured lawn." It features a cluster of charming homes, plenty of front yards and winding side streets to hide in, and a neighborhood full of nooks and crannies necessary to run from (or stop) Michael. 

Check it out in the Haddonfield Heights trailer for yourself below: 

As a civilian, you will have to scavenge for supplies, guide residents to safety, and locate a phone to call the police before the time runs out in Haddonfield Heights. And if you're playing as Michael, you can expect to prowl the shadows and use abilities like Shape Jump to traverse through the neighborhood unseen and strike without warning. 

"This neighborhood allowed us to reimage the tension of Haddonfield in a way that feels both intimate and terrifying," IllFonic design director Jordan Mathewson writes in a press release. "We wanted players to feel the comfort of the neighborhood they recognize from the film right before we turn it into a panic. Every hedge, hallway, and backyard was built to heighten suspense and reward clever play, whether you're hunting or being hunted." 

Halloween launches on PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X/S, and PC via Steam and the Epic Games Store on Tuesday, September 8, 2026. 

In the meantime, read Game Informer's exclusive interview with IllFonic about the game.

While players continue to develop their settlement, story-driven quests, time-sensitive expeditions, and dynamic fog surges can shift entire strategies in a moment.

The main antagonist is an enigmatic fog, which impacts citizens’ health and morale, and is modeled using custom voxel grid technology, creating dynamic and unpredictable fog shifts. A once-thriving society faced a life-threatening enemy when this mysterious mist swept across the lands, warping their minds and consuming everything. In a desperate attempt for survival, those who still stood fled upwards towards the treetops, and rebuilt their homes above the deadly haze. The game’s heavy atmosphere is paired with ambisonic audio cues that intensify the sense of dread, all woven together by the haunting compositions of legendary musician Akira Yamaoka.

Key Features

  • Build a variety of buildings—industrial, social, and defensive. Research new technologies and develop specialized machinery to advance your treetop city. Build high, build safe!
  • Manage scarce resources, balance the distribution of raw materials between construction, defense, and the needs of your residents. Distribute wisely!
  • Light up the streets to repel the fog, fortify defenses, and make difficult choices to secure the survival of your city. Save lives, protect souls!
  • Venture into the fog to gather rare resources and uncover ancient artifacts. Lead expeditions to rescue survivors and push the story forward. Understand the Fog, uncover its origins!
  • Develop your city’s leaders and unravel an epic story through quests, objectives, and side missions, all centered around four main protagonists.

item.title: Lunar Strike launches in May 2026
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS5
  • Xbox Series

Science-fiction narrative adventure and exploration game dated.

Science-fiction narrative adventure and exploration game Lunar Strike will launch for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and PC via Steam in May 2026, developer Cognition Europe announced.

Here is an overview of the game, via Cognition Europe:

About

Lunar Strike is a single-player narrative adventure and exploration game set on the Moon’s South Pole in the year 2119.

You play as a junior archivist sent to document humanity’s final lunar colony. Your mission begins with scanning and preserving scientific, cultural, and personal records.

But when sabotage destabilizes the colony, the task shifts to survival under real lunar conditions: managing oxygen, power, and time while deciding what knowledge and memory must endure. Every choice shapes the archive—and the outcome of the colony itself.

Developed with ethical questions of legacy, memory, and responsibility at its heart, players will face increasingly difficult challenges to build and preserve the archive, with multiple outcomes driven by their decisions and values.

Key Features

  • Rich, Multi-Faceted Narrative – Preserve the culture of the last remaining lunar colony while making game-altering decisions that impact the story, unravelling a new future for humanity.
  • No Combat – Lunar Strike focuses on survival, scanning, puzzle solving, and decision-making. The gameplay unfolds under time pressures, environmental degradation, and mounting ethical tension.
  • Grounded in Hard Science – Developed in collaboration with space researchers, the game incorporates realistic systems and hazards, including 1/6th lunar gravity, toxic Moon dust, and real-world physics.
  • Cultural Heritage as Gameplay – Preserve humanity’s story on the Moon. Through 3D scanning, photogrammetry, and archival logic, capture the final traces of lunar life before its collapse.
  • Rooted in Real Ethics and Science Fiction – Inspired by real-life heritage efforts, built by creators with backgrounds in cultural preservation and storytelling, Lunar Strike invites thoughtful engagement with space exploration.

item.title: Cellar Door Games announces roguelike strategy RPG Neath for PC
item.content:encoded:
Rogue Legacy series developer Cellar Door Games has announced roguelike strategy RPG Neath for PC (Steam). It will launch in 2026.

“With deep inspiration from not only video games like Into the Breach, but also tabletop board games such as Mansions of Madness, Neath is a game we’ve been wanting to make for years,” said Cellar Door Games co-founder and lead programmer Kenny Lee in a press release. “Development has taken us far from our comfort zone, working in an unfamiliar genre with an aesthetic much darker than what we usually do. But we’ve got a lot of new ideas, from ‘engagement locking’ to the ‘attack resolve system’, and we’re excited to see if we can move this burgeoning genre in a whole new direction. PRAISE NEATH!”

Here is an overview of the game, via its Steam page:

About

Praise Neath.

Lead a band of fragile warriors through a colossal, inverted tower, where Taboos, the everchanging edicts of a God, warp the laws of reality.

Neath is a roguelike tactical RPG set in a decaying world shadowed by an irradiated, inverted tower. Using a fluid turn-based system where the turn order is always shifting, you dictate the actions of both friend and foe alike. As enemies engage you they will freeze your teammates in fear. Disrupt opponents by knocking them away, shove allies far from impending harm, or make the ultimate sacrifice and have someone else take the blow in their stead.

As you ascend the corrupt citadel to defy the decree of the undivine, your journey will twist and turn with encounters shown through a classic 90’s dungeon-crawler style. Unlock new abilities and challenges that ensure every expedition is unique, and unravel a dark mystery before you succumb to the horrors within.

  • ❮
  • ❯

Key Features

  • Control Every “Moment” – A unique “engagement-locking” system grips your teammates in fear when they are targeted by enemies, and you must disrupt your foes to save them. In Neath there are no heroes. Work together to survive, or stand alone and fall.
  • Ascend the Inverted Tower – Face your fears as you ascend the ever-changing inverted tower of Neath in a roguelike tactical RPG where every run is unique.
  • Defy Fate – Make trapped chests fizzle, barter with the gods, and reshape destiny with the power of Fate’s Die. Encounter special events inspired by classic 90’s dungeon-crawlers that reshapes your party during every run. But beware the consequences when playing games with providence.
  • Ever-Changing Encounters – Build your party throughout the run to learn new abilities and uncover ancient, powerful relics. Build esoteric synergies that will have you poisoning the air with rotting stench, or striking blows that send enemies hurtling across the room.
  • Shape Your Settlement – Build up the lowly town of Shale to better prepare you to climb deeper into the depths of the tower. Distribute your serfdom to prioritize skills that adjust your playstyle before every run.
  • Praise Neath – The Taboos must be honoured. The Taboo must be obeyed. Tithe the gods; say their name. Laws may change, but the punishment remains the same. Praise Neath.

Watch the announcement trailer below. View the first screenshots at the gallery.

item.title: Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024's New Crossover Is One You'll Never Expect
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Microsoft has announced the next crossover collaboration for Microsoft Flight Simulator 24, and it's none other than Netflix's hugely popular Stranger Things.

"Turn the skies upside down," Microsoft said in its announcement for a collaboration set to come to the game on December 9. The teaser video doesn't give much away, but one possibility is that the upcoming crossover will allow people to fly through Hawkins, the setting of Stranger Things.

If you look closely, you can see the aircraft in question in the video is a UH-1H Huey helicopter with the "Hawkins Heli-Tours" logo emblazoned on it.

It's unknown if this will be a free or paid add-on for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024, but those details and more should become clear in the days ahead.

Microsoft Flight Simulator 24's Stranger Things crossover arrives one day after the game lands on PS5 on December 8. People who bought one of the game's more expensive editions can play Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 right now in early access.

As for Stranger Things, the show's fifth and final season debuted on November 26 with the first volume of episodes. The second batch arrives on December 25, followed by the two-hour finale on December 31.
